key_mistakes.reason: Black's move c6 is a passive response to e4, allowing White to gain central control. The Caro-Kann is a solid opening but requires precise play.
Black played c5, allowing White to maintain a strong pawn on e5 and control the center without much opposition. It also weakens the d5 square.
Developing the knight to c6 without addressing the central tension allowed White to increase control. Better play involves challenging the center.
The move e6 did not capitalize on the opportunity to resolve the central tension and allowed White to consolidate. It also blocks the bishop on f8.
Playing Be7 was a passive move when Black needed to counterattack or exert pressure on White's center.
Nd6 allowed White to simplify in a position where Black needed more dynamic play. It resulted in an exchange that favored White.
Qg4 was an overly aggressive move that led to a loss of material after Black's best responses.
Bxg6 blundered a piece, as it allowed Black to capture the queen with no compensation.

recommendations: Focus on controlling the center with pawns and pieces.
Develop pieces actively and try to resolve central tension favorably.
Avoid unnecessary exchanges that simplify the position in favor of the opponent.
Be cautious of tactical threats and ensure moves are well-calculated before execution.
